scales.name: Communicating
scales.leftDescription: Good communication is precise, simple, and clear. Messages are expressed and understood at face value.
scales.rightDescription: Good communication is sophisticated, nuanced, and layered. Messages are often implied but not plainly expressed.

scales.name: Evaluating
scales.leftDescription: Negative feedback is provided frankly, bluntly, and honestly. Criticism may be given to an individual in front of a group.
scales.rightDescription: Negative feedback is provided softly, subtly, and diplomatically. Criticism is given only in private.

scales.name: Persuading
scales.leftDescription: Individuals prefer to first understand the theory or concept before moving to practical application.
scales.rightDescription: Individuals prefer to begin with practical examples and applications before discussing theory.

scales.name: Leading
scales.leftDescription: The ideal distance between boss and subordinate is low. The best boss is a facilitator among equals.
scales.rightDescription: The ideal distance between boss and subordinate is high. The best boss is a strong director.

scales.name: Deciding
scales.leftDescription: Decisions are made in groups through unanimous agreement. Decisions take longer but are more committed.
scales.rightDescription: Decisions are made by individuals, usually the boss. Decisions are fast but may be revisited.
scales.note: This scale is independent of the Leading scale. A hierarchical culture can still make decisions consensually.

scales.name: Trusting
scales.leftDescription: Trust is built through business-related activities. Work relationships are built and dropped easily.
scales.rightDescription: Trust is built through sharing meals, drinks, and personal time. Work relationships build slowly over time.

scales.name: Disagreeing
scales.leftDescription: Disagreement and debate are positive for the team. Open confrontation is appropriate and acceptable.
scales.rightDescription: Disagreement and debate are negative for the team. Open confrontation is inappropriate and disruptive.

scales.name: Scheduling
scales.leftDescription: Project steps are approached sequentially. One thing at a time. No interruptions. Punctuality and deadlines are rigid.
scales.rightDescription: Project steps are approached fluidly. Many things are dealt with at once. Interruptions accepted. Flexibility valued.
